{{Infobox magazine | title = All About Accounting | image_file = vobu_page_ua.png | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | editor = [[Petro Krychun]] | editor_title = head editor | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | frequency = 120 numbers yearly | circulation = 93,100 | category = [[Accountancy]] | company = | publisher = | firstdate = {{Start date|1994|05|01}} | country = [[Ukraine]] | based = [[Kiev]] | language = [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]]
[[Russian language|Russian]] | website = {{URL|vobu.ua}} | issn = 1682-508X }} [[File:Vobu1.PNG|thumb|270px|Front Page of first issue]] '''All About Accounting''' ''({{lang-uk|Все про бухгалтерський облік}})'' is a semiweekly [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] and [[Russian language|Russian]]-language [[newspaper]] based in [[Kiev]] ([[Ukraine]]) with a run of 93,100. Published since 1994. ==History== :1993 – newspaper was established. :1994 – The first newspaper issue publication, run of 17000 copies. :1995 – Newspaper format changes from 16 to 32 pages. :1996 – The 100th issue of the newspaper is revealed to the world, run of 50000 copies. :1997 – The newspaper becomes a semiweekly periodical. In addition, subscribers are now receiving two subject special editions on monthly basis. :1998 – New service for subscribers comes to life: taxation and accounting report forms, together with a quarterly publications catalogue. The newspaper becomes the first Ukrainian accounting periodical to be published in both Russian and Ukrainian languages. :1999 – The 400th issue of the newspaper, with a run reaching 74500 copies, is published. The periodical becomes a laureate of Vyshcha Proba (eng. The Highest Probe) countrywide contest. :2000 – New service comes to life: the subscribers are able to contact the editorial board through round-the-clock telephone help-line. A My Tax Officer Is The Best contest is organized in collaboration with the Tax Administration of Ukraine. :2001 – The newspaper is awarded with the Honorary Diploma and Commemorative Decoration of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine. The management of the editorial board is awarded with President’s of Ukraine Commendation. The editorial board provides Ukrainian institutes, universities, technical schools and colleges, having an accounting major and running accounting courses, with specialized subject information. :2002 – The 700th issue of the newspaper, with a run of 90600 copies, is published. The Best [[Accountant]] of Ukraine contest is held,{{Cite web |url=http://www.aval.ua/en/about/history/history_2002/ |title=Raiffeisen Bank Aval — chronology |access-date=2010-11-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904184344/http://www.aval.ua/en/about/history/history_2002/ |archive-date=2011-09-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }} with 540 accountants from all over Ukraine becoming winners. :The management of the editorial board is awarded with President’s of Ukraine Commendation. :2003 – First free consultation line dedicated to accounting and tax assessment matters is created. The subscribers now are provided with exclusive additions: Hotels of Ukraine, Foreign-Economic Activity Reference Book, and Samples of Basic Documents Completion. The management of the editorial board is awarded with the Honorary Diploma of the [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]]. :2004 – The newspaper celebrates its 10th anniversary. The periodical website is created - [http://www.vobu.com.ua www.vobu.com.ua]. Subject-oriented internet forums of the newspaper ([http://forum.vobu.com.ua .forum.vobu.com.ua]) are operating. The periodical becomes one of principal originators for the official Accountant’s Day, July 16, celebration.{{ru icon}} [http://www.sta-crimea.gov.ua/uprotd14-arhieve1557.html State Tax Administration of the Autonomous Republic of Crimea: the Triple Alliance] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716162237/http://www.sta-crimea.gov.ua/uprotd14-arhieve1557.html |date=2011-07-16 }} :My Director Is The Best contest is held. 255 best directors of companies from all over Ukraine are selected. [[Verkhovna Rada]], the Ukrainian parliament, awards the newspaper with the Honorary Diploma. :2005 – The newspaper becomes an indisputable leader on professional periodicals market. The run reaches 93100 copies. A Digital Accountants Calendar application is developed. :2006 – Accountants’ Information System (AIS-service) is initiated. The service provides free support for accountants, managers, lawyers, and entrepreneurs through email, as well as allows ordering normative documents, legislation news, and report forms to an email address. A Turn-key Subscription promotion is organized, with 3 contestants winning apartments in Kyiv. :2007 – The largest number of forum participants is registered – 252 persons were simultaneously visiting the newspaper’s forum. A Mysteries of Egypt promotion is held, with 230 accountants winning vouchers for a journey to Egypt. :2008 – A 15 Years Together or All About Success in Accounting promotion is held. 15 accountants are granted cars. Content management concept if reviewed, as well as the newspaper’s design. A help-line with representatives of the State Treasury of Ukraine, the Ministry of Education and Science, the Ministry of Healthcare, and the Ministry of Culture and Sport starts operating. :For the first time the all-Ukrainian contest for the best author of a budget accounting publication is held among employees of the State Treasury of Ukraine.{{uk icon}} [http://www.treasury.gov.ua/main/uk/publish/article/70514 State Treasury of Ukraine and "All about accounting" newspaper announced the contest "The best author of budgetary accounting"] :The Best Student’s Article contest is held among students of Ukrainian institutes and colleges.{{uk icon}} [http://www.khadi.kharkov.ua/ua/business-fac/default.asp?id=23&mnu=23&ACT=5&content=44 Faculty of Business and Administration: scientific activities] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314204907/http://www.khadi.kharkov.ua/ua/business-fac/default.asp?id=23&mnu=23&ACT=5&content=44 |date=2012-03-14 }} :With the assistance of the State Treasury of Ukraine the newspaper starts a Treasurer column, which contains up-to-date comments and explanations dedicated to accounting matters in state-financed organizations. :2009 – The subscribers get free CDs containing report forms. A Generous Gifts promotion is held, with 1625 Ukrainian accountants winning money rewards. A CD containing normative documents for state institutions accountants is released. :The Yaskrave Radio ({{en icon}} Bright Radio) starts [[broadcasting]] at www.vobu.com.ua website. :Special editions of the newspaper now have color cover. :New format is introduced to The Super-Table, popular reference source among accountants. :2010 – As a result of collaboration of the State Tax Administration of Ukraine and the editorial board, 125 Questions About Taxation, a special edition of the newspaper, is published. The edition contains answers given by tax officers from all over Ukraine. :On the occasion of 15th anniversary of the State Treasury of Ukraine, a second contest for the best author of a budget accounting publication is held. :The newspaper now has specialized columns and larger number of pages. :The Best Mentor contest, organized at the official website of the ''All about accounting'' newspaper,{{uk icon}} [http://impo.ubs.gov.ua/?id=152&lang=1 Masters and postgraduate education institute - "Bright radio" and All about accounting newspaper transmitting Contest "Favorite Teacher"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818113616/http://impo.ubs.gov.ua/?id=152&lang=1 |date=2011-08-18 }} is held, with 200000 voters taking part in it; every institute, university, technical school and college in Ukraine selects and awards its favorite faculty staff member with the Best Mentor of Ukraine Honorary Diploma. :New creative projects, Inspection: Practice of Defense and Bankruptcy, are launched. :On October 23, 2010, the editorial board of the ''All about accounting'' newspaper created the largest newspaper in the world.{{uk icon}} [http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/index.php?id=4&listid=131424 In Independence Square, Kiev Presentation of the largest newspaper in the world] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104055246/http://nrcu.gov.ua/index.php?id=4&listid=131424 |date=2010-11-04 }}. – The National Radio Company of Ukraine, 23 October 2010.{{uk icon}}[http://www.unian.net/ukr/news/news-402408.html The largest newspaper in the world has been shown in Kiev, Ukraine (photo)]. – [[UNIAN]], 23 October 2010. Its dimensions amounting to 126 (320 cm) inches at height and 89 (226 cm) inches in width, and being opened – 126 (320 cm) inches at height and 178 (452 cm) inches in width. The newspaper is by ten times larger than a regular size of ''All about Accounting'' issue. The new record was accepted as a world record by the Ukrainian Book of Records.[http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/order/?id=202151 Ukraine creates world's largest newspaper ] – [[Ukrinform]], 23 October 2010.{{Cite web |url=http://www.vobu.com.ua/blanki/award/ |title=Diploma of Ukrainian Book of Records # 33/02-02368 |access-date=2010-11-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314204910/http://www.vobu.com.ua/blanki/award/ |archive-date=2012-03-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Editorial staff== * O. G. Stepoviy – chief editor; * [[Petro Krychun|P. M. Krychun]] – head editor; * V. S. Kaplun – director. ==Awards== * Laureate of Vyshcha Proba countrywide contest – 1999; * Honorary Diploma of the [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]] – 2001;[[:File:Kmu2.jpg|Honorary Diploma of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine # 2220]] * Diploma of the [[Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]] – 2004;[[:File:Vru2.jpg|Diploma of the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine # 682]] * Diploma of Ministry of Fuel and Energy of Ukraine – 2004;{{uk icon}} [http://mpe.kmu.gov.ua/fuel/doccatalog/document?id=50141 Order # 57-K / S to award the diploma of the Ministry of Fuel and Energy of Ukraine (doc)] * Diploma of Ukrainian Book of Records – 2010. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{uk icon}} [http://www.vobu.com.ua www.vobu.com.ua – site] * {{uk icon}} [http://forum.vobu.com.ua/ forum.vobu.com.ua – forum] * {{uk icon}} [http://www.vobu.com.ua/ukr/radio vobu.com.ua/ukr/radio – Yaskrave Radio] * {{uk icon}} [http://www.vobu.biz/ www.vobu.biz – Digital Accountants Calendar] [[Category:Magazines established in 1993]] [[Category:Ukrainian magazines]] [[Category:Accounting in Ukraine]] [[Category:Russian-language magazines]] [[Category:Magazines published in Kiev]] [[Category:Accounting magazines]] [[Category:1993 establishments in Ukraine]]

[[File:Bankenviertel (Banking District) in Frankfurt.png|thumb|The Bankenviertel has no exact borders, but is commonly defined as the western part of the [[Innenstadt (Frankfurt am Main)|Innenstadt]], the southern part of the [[Westend (Frankfurt am Main)|Westend]] and the eastern part of the [[Bahnhofsviertel (Frankfurt am Main)|Bahnhofsviertel]]]] '''Bankenviertel''' ({{IPA-de|ˈbaŋkn̩ˌfɪɐ̯tl̩}}; ''banking district'') is the name of the [[central business district]] in [[Frankfurt]], [[Germany]]. It designates an area in the city centre where many banks, insurance companies, and other financial institutions are located. It is the most important [[financial centre]] in Germany and one of the largest in Europe along with [[La Défense]] in the [[Paris aire urbaine]] and [[London]]'s [[City of London|City]] and [[Canary Wharf]]. Having no official or strict borders, it is commonly defined as the western part of the [[Innenstadt (Frankfurt am Main)|Innenstadt]], the southern part of the [[Westend (Frankfurt am Main)|Westend]] and the eastern part of the [[Bahnhofsviertel (Frankfurt am Main)|Bahnhofsviertel]]. Its most central square is the [[Opernplatz]]. [[File:Frankfurt Skyline Pano.Südwest.20130618.jpg|thumb|800px|center|Panorama view seen from of Bankenviertel from the southeast]] == Location == [[File:Frankfurt Skyline bei Nacht.Osten.20140330.jpg|thumb|Skyline at night]] [[File:Frankfurt Am Main-Zeil-vom Maintower aus gesehen.jpg|thumb|View over [[Zeil]]]] [[File:Hauptwache Frankfurt am Main.jpg|thumb|Bankenviertel with [[Hauptwache (Frankfurt am Main)|Hauptwache]]]] [[File:Eurotower-04-09.jpg|thumb|Eurotower of the ECB]] [[File:Skyline of Frankfurt from Goetheturm on a hazy evening 140827 1.jpg|thumb|View from the former [[Goethe Tower]] in the south]] The Bankenviertel is not an official city district and has no officially or strictly defined borders. It stretches across three city districts: the western part of the [[Innenstadt (Frankfurt am Main)|Innenstadt]], the southern part of the [[Westend (Frankfurt am Main)|Westend]] and the eastern part of the [[Bahnhofsviertel (Frankfurt am Main)|Bahnhofsviertel]]. Many of the largest banks in Germany, e.g. [[Deutsche Bank]], [[DZ Bank]], [[Commerzbank]] and [[Helaba]], have their corporate headquarters here, as well as many representation offices of foreign banks. It is also the place where most of [[List of tallest buildings in Frankfurt|Frankfurts high-rises and skyscrapers]] are located, which gave it also the nicknames Bankfurt and [[Mainhattan]]. The heart of the Bankenviertel is located on both sides of the Taunus- and Gallusanlage, an inner-city parkway, and the surrounding streets (Neue Mainzer Straße, Junghofstraße, Kaiserstraße), and the central square of the Bankenviertel is the [[Opernplatz]]. Furthermore, the area on both sides of the [[Mainzer Landstraße]] from Taunusanlage to Platz der Republik and the Bockenheimer Landstraße, beginning at the [[Alte Oper|Opernplatz]], are part of the area. The Bankenviertel also includes the areas near the Opernplatz on its eastern side, notably the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange]] 300 meters east of the Opernplatz, as well as a number of banks in its immediate vicinity. == Financial institutions == {| class="wikitable zebra" |- ! Eight of nine suburban [[Rhine-Main S-Bahn|S-Bahn]] lines (S1-S6, S8, S9) serve the stations [[Frankfurt Hauptwache station|Hauptwache]], [[Frankfurt Taunusanlage station|Taunusanlage]] and [[Frankfurt Central Station]]. All inner-city [[Frankfurt U-Bahn|U-Bahn]] lines have stops within the area: U1-U3 at Willy-Brandt-Platz and Hauptwache, U4 and U5 at Willy-Brandt-Platz and Frankfurt Central Station, U6 and U7 at Hauptwache and Alte Oper. The tram lines 11 and 12 stop at Frankfurt Central Station and Willy-Brandt-Platz, and the lines 16 and 17 link the central station and the [[Frankfurt Trade Fair]] area. == References == {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Hesse}} {{Bankenviertel}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Bankenviertel| ]] [[Category:Districts of Frankfurt]] [[Category:Financial districts in Germany|Frankfurt am Main]] [[Category:Central business districts|Frankfurt am Main]]

revision.text:
The '''Becher Process''' is an [[industrial process]] used to upgrade [[ilmenite]] to [[synthetic rutile]].
The [[mineral]], ilmenite, contains 55-65% [[titanium]] as [[Titanium dioxide|TiO<sub>2</sub>]], the rest being [[iron oxide]]. The Becher process removes the iron oxide, leaving a residue of [[synthetic rutile]], which is more than 90% TiO<sub>2</sub>.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chemlink.com.au/titan_rutile.htm| title=Rutile and ilmenite - Australian production and potential profile}}</ref>
== History == This technology was developed in the early 1960s in [[Western Australia]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australianminesatlas.gov.au/info/factsheets/titanium.jsp |title=Australian Atlas of Mineral Resources Mineral Sands Fact Sheet |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830005748/http://www.australianminesatlas.gov.au/info/factsheets/titanium.jsp |archivedate=2007-08-30 |df= }}</ref> by a joint initiative between industry and government. The process was named after [[Robert Gordon Becher]], who while working at the Western Australian Government Chemical Laboratories invented, developed and introduced the technique to the Western Australian Mineral Sands industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cluniesross.org.au/the-awards/previous-award-winners/1992-award-winners/ |title=ATSE Clunies Ross Foundation Medal Awards - 1992 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The process was patented in 1961.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com.au/patents/WO1996024699A1?cl=en|title=Treatment of titanium-containing material |publisher=CLAIMS Patent Services|accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref>
== Process ==
The Becher Process is suitable for [[weathered]] ilmenite that has low [[concentration]]s of [[chromium]] and [[magnesium]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wwwscience.murdoch.edu.au/teach/m358/titanium.pdf |title=Murdoch University Titanium |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061201183427/http://wwwscience.murdoch.edu.au/teach/m358/titanium.pdf |archivedate=2006-12-01 |df= }}</ref> There are four steps involved in removing the iron portion of the ilmentite: # [[Oxidation]] # [[Redox]] # [[Aeration]] # [[Leaching (chemical science)|Leaching]]
===Oxidation=== Oxidation involves heating the ilmenite in a rotary kiln with air to convert all of the iron in the ilmenite grains to [[iron(III) oxide]]:
: 4 FeTiO<sub>3</sub> <sub>(s)</sub> + O<sub>2</sub> <sub>(g)</sub> → 2 Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>·TiO<sub>2</sub> <sub>(s)</sub> + 2 TiO<sub>2</sub> <sub>(s)</sub>
This allows for use of a wide range of ilmenite materials with varying Fe(II) and Fe(III) content to be used in the next step.
===Reduction=== Reduction is performed in a rotary kiln with pseudobrookite (Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>.TiO<sub>2</sub>), coal and sulfur, then heated to a temperature greater than 1200 °C.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.education.cmewa.com.au/images/1_MineralSands.pdf |title=Chamber of Minerals and Energy Western Australia - Mineral Sands Factsheet |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704132348/http://www.education.cmewa.com.au/images/1_MineralSands.pdf |archivedate=2008-07-04 |df= }}</ref> The iron oxide in the mineral grains is reduced to metallic iron to produce reduced ilmenite:
: Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>·TiO<sub>2</sub> <sub>(s)</sub> + 3 CO <sub>(g)</sub> → 2 Fe <sub>(s)</sub> + TiO<sub>2</sub> <sub>(s)</sub> + 3 CO<sub>2</sub> <sub>(g)</sub>
Once the Reduced Ilmenite has cooled it is separated from the char by screening, then continues to the next step of the process.
===Aeration=== Aeration involves the removal of the metallic iron created in the last step by "rusting" it out. This is achieved in large tanks that contain 1% [[ammonium chloride]] solution with air being pumped through the tank. The tank is being continuously agitated, and the iron will rust and precipitate out of solution, away from the titanium dioxide portion in the form of a slime.
: 4 Fe <sub>(s)</sub> + 3 O<sub>2</sub> <sub>(g)</sub> → 2Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>
The finer iron oxide is then separated from the larger particles of synthetic rutile.
=== Acid Leach === Once the majority of the Iron Oxide has been removed the remainder of it is leached away using 0.5M [[sulfuric acid]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wipo.int/pctdb/en/wo.jsp?WO=1994%2F03647&IA=WO1994%2F03647&DISPLAY=DESC |title=WIPO-WO/1994/003647 TREATMENT OF TITANIFEROUS MATERIALS }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zujA_cdC-msC&pg=PA381 |title=Mineral Processing Technology Mpt-2005 |accessdate=10 July 2013}} *{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tFbrWA9jWS4C&pg=PA31 |title=Titanium Dioxide |accessdate=10 July 2013}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Becher Process}} <!--Categories--> [[Category:Chemical processes]] [[Category:Industrial processes]]

page.title: Bilan d'aptitude délivré par les grandes écoles

revision.comment: ±[[Category:Higher education]]→[[Category:Higher education in France]]; ±[[Category:Qualifications]]→[[Category:Academic degrees of France]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''Bilan d'aptitude délivré par les grandes écoles''' ('''BADGE''', in English '''Assessment of competency issued by ''grandes écoles''''') is a [[France|French]] degree created in 2001 by the ''[[Conférence des Grandes Écoles]]''<ref>{{fr icon}} [http://www.vocatis.fr/article.php3?id_article=15243 BADGE : le label formation continue des Grandes écoles]</ref> and primarily intended for owners of a two-year degree after the ''[[Baccalauréat]]''.
== Presentation ==
According to the rules of organization of training programs accredited by the ''[[Conférence des Grandes Écoles]]'' , ""The BADGE ... of the School... " is a registered collective ownership of the ''[[Conférence des Grandes Écoles]]'', attributed to a specific training organized by a school member of the [[Conférence des Grandes Écoles|CGE]]. It is intended primarily for owners of a two-year degree after the ''[[Baccalauréat]]'".
Be considered applicants who hold one of the following qualifications: * Two-year degree after the ''[[Baccalauréat]]''; * ''[[Baccalauréat]]'' and a significant professional experience relevant to the subject of the application of at least five years.
The BADGE program necessarily includes a number of common elements: at least 200 hours of instruction, including theoretical, practical work, team projects and possibly [[distance learning]] and a final validation test. The program takes place over a period of 7 weeks to 24 months maximum, subject to alternating training / business where the period exceeds 6 months and is 15 to 25 [[ECTS-credits]].<ref>{{fr icon}} [http://www.cge.asso.fr/BADGE/Regl_int_BADGE.phtml REGLEMENT INTERIEUR DU B.A.D.G.E. DE LA CONFERENCE DES GRANDES ECOLES]</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.cge.asso.fr/en/nos-labels/badge BADGE on ''Conférence des grandes écoles'' website]
{{Conférence des Grandes Écoles}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bilan d'aptitude delivre par les grandes ecoles}} [[Category:Management education]] [[Category:Higher education in France]] [[Category:Academic degrees of France]]

revision.comment: template
revision.text:
A '''business alliance''' is an agreement between businesses, usually motivated by [[cost reduction]] and improved service for the customer. Alliances are often bounded by a single agreement with [[Equity (economics)|equitable]] [[risk]] and opportunity share for all parties involved and are typically managed by an integrated project team. An example of this is [[code sharing]] in [[airline alliance]]s.
==Types== There are five basic categories or types of alliances:<ref name="Kuglin">{{cite book| last = Kuglin | first = F.A. | authorlink = |author2=J. Hook | title = Building, Leading, and Managing Strategic Alliances: How to Work Effectively and Profitably With Partner Companies | publisher = American Management Association | date = 2002 | location = | pages = | url = | doi = | id = }}</ref>
*Sales: A sales alliance occurs when two companies agree to go to market together to sell complementary products and services. *Solution-specific: A solution-specific alliance occurs when two companies agree to jointly develop and sell a specific marketplace solution. *Geographic-specific: A geographic-specific alliance is developed when two companies agree to jointly market or [[co-brand]] their products and services in a specific geographic region. *Investment: An investment alliance occurs when two companies agree to join their funds for mutual investment. *Joint venture: A [[joint venture]] is an alliance that occurs when two or more companies agree to undertake economic activity together.
In many cases, alliances between companies can involve two or more categories or types of alliances.
== Horizontal alliances ==
A type of an alliance is a horizontal alliance. For example, a horizontal alliance can occur between [[logistics |logistics service providers]], i.e., the cooperation between two or more logistics companies that are potentially competing.<ref name="rauewieland">Raue, J.S. & Wieland, A. (2015), [http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/pdfplus/10.1108/IJLM-08-2012-0083 The interplay of different types of governance in horizontal cooperations: a view on logistics service providers]. The International Journal of Logistics Management, Vol. 26, No. 2.</ref> In a horizontal alliance, these partners can benefit twofold. On one hand, they can "access tangible resources which are directly exploitable." In this example extending common transportation networks, their warehouse infrastructure and the ability to provide more complex service packages can be achieved by combining resources. On the other hand, partners can "access intangible resources, which are not directly exploitable." This typically includes know-how and information and, in turn, innovation.<ref name="rauewieland"/>
==See also== * [[Business group]] * [[Competition regulator]] * [[Strategic alliance]]
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}} ;Bibliography * [http://www.rambaonline.com/en/ Russian-American Business Alliance ] *{{cite book | last =Darby | first =Mark | title =Alliance Brand: Fulfilling the Promise of Partnering | publisher =[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]]| date =2006 | isbn =978-0-470-03218-3 }}
{{Business organizations}} [[Category:Business terms]]

revision.comment: /* Major players */
revision.text:
[[File:Group 4 Securicor van 105.jpg|thumb|200px|G4S Cash Services CVIT VAN (UK)]] [[File:Armored-truck.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Prosegur]] Armored car in Barcelona]] '''Cash-in-transit''' ('''CIT''') or '''cash/valuables-in-transit''' ('''CVIT''') is the physical transfer of [[banknotes]], [[coins]], [[credit cards]] and items of value from one location to another. The locations include cash centers and bank branches, ATM points, large retailers and other premises holding large amounts of cash such as ticket vending machines and parking meters.
Many cash in transit companies are [[private security]] companies that offer cash handling as part of their services. [[Loomis (company)|Loomis]] is today the only major CIT business that is fully dedicated to cash handling after the split from [[Securitas (Swedish security company)|Securitas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.securitas.com/en/News/Press-Releases/2006/Securitas-Cash-Handling-Services-announces-new-international-brand-identity-Loomis/|title=Securitas Cash Handling Services announces new international brand identity "Loomis"|accessdate=18 Nov 2013|publisher=Securitas Group}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.loomis.com/en/Business-amp-Markets/Our-business/|title=Our Business|accessdate=18 Nov 2013|publisher=Loomis AB}}</ref> Brinks spun off its home security division setting the focus as well on cash handling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-brinks-company-to-spin-off-brinks-home-security-to-shareholders-57117492.html|title=The Brink's Company to Spin-Off Brink's Home Security to Shareholders|accessdate=18 Nov 2013|publisher=PR Newswire}}</ref>
By law, the CIT companies are seen as [[Logistics|logistic]] companies in the [[private security]] industry and therefore have to comply with transport and security legislation. In some countries, the transportation of cash has its own [[legislation]] (for example, Europe has varying CIT laws<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coess.org/_Uploads/dbsAttachedFiles/Comparative_overview_CIT_legislation_15_MS_full_text_EN.pdf |title=A comparative overview of the legislations governing the Cash in Transit private industry in the 15 EU members |accessdate=18 Nov 2013 |publisher=Confederation of European Security Services |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030171801/http://www.coess.org/_Uploads/dbsAttachedFiles/Comparative_overview_CIT_legislation_15_MS_full_text_EN.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-30 |df= }}</ref>). The CIT industry is regulated by national, regional and local legislation, social regulations and current practices. Responsible authorities are usually the [[Ministry of the Interior]], the [[Ministry of Justice]] and the [[police]]. Legislation and regulations may impose requirements and restrictions on use of [[firearms]], types of vehicles, minimum number of crew members, and use of [[Intelligent banknote neutralisation system|Intelligent Banknote Neutralisation Systems]].
CIT services can be carried out in [[soft-skinned]], semi-armoured or armoured vehicles. The use of soft-skinned vehicles is normally only allowed when alternative security methods, such as [[intelligent banknote neutralisation system]]s, are also used. Security cases containing IBNS are provided by companies as StrongPoint Cash Security and Oberthür. Such CIT is commonly referred to as “Light CIT”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/publications/publication16271_en.pdf |title=EU WHITE PAPER ON PROFESSIONAL CROSS BORDER TRANSPORTATION OF EURO CASH BY ROAD – EBF WISHLIST |accessdate=18 Nov 2013 |publisher=European Banking Federation }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Services == Inside CIT, the companies are specialized in the transportation and processing of cash and valuables, [[precious metals]]. They transport [[banknotes]], [[coins]], bulk cash, [[diamonds]], non-personalised [[smart cards]], non-personalised [[passports]] and other valuables. That is why, in many countries, the service was renamed 'Asset handling' or 'Asset-in-transit'.
== Cash processing == Cash processing is an industrial process far removed from traditional banking activities and culture. The internal organization of cash handling within banks is often obsolete and inefficient, inherited from old bank organizations and further complicated by mergers, acquisitions and restructuring. This has led the majority of banks to opt for the outsourcing of wholesale cash processing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esta-cash.eu/documents/budapest-documents/cash_outsourcing___cash_recycling___niven___smith.pdf|title=Session IV: Cash Outsourcing and Cash Recycling|accessdate=18 Nov 2013|publisher=European Security Transport Association}}</ref>
There are on the other hand inherent difficulties associated with outsourcing. One of them is the loss of control and the reliance on external providers. In some cases, banks no longer have the know-how in relation to cash handling.
Cash processing has evolved from a labor-intensive activity focused on the transportation of cash to a capital-intensive industry offering end-to end solutions. Transport no longer constitutes the value added in the business but continues to structure the organization. The CIT’s footprint remains a key factor of selection by banks and retailers.
The industry is generally divided into two sectors: Processing, and ATM servicing
==Major players== Five companies command nearly 60% of the global CIT market (2010).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.g4s.com/~/media/Files/Financial%20Presentations/London%20Cash%20Centre%20Presentation.ashx|title=Cash Solutions|accessdate=18 Nov 2013|publisher=G4S}}</ref> They are: * [[Brink's]] – 23% * [[G4S]] – 15% * [[Loomis (company)|Loomis]] – 12% * [[Prosegur]] – 7% * [[Garda (security company)|Garda]] – 4% * [[GSLS]] – 0.01% * Others – 39%
Few companies outside these five have cross-border operations. This is in part seen as a result of the significant cost to establish a CIT operation.
== CIT guards == Most armored cars have two to three occupants: * A [[driver (person)|driver]], who is normally never allowed to leave the vehicle until it returns to the garage * 1–2 guards who deliver the cash or valuables
Depending on the jurisdiction, the guards are armed with weapons. Most guards are issued with [[shotgun]]s, while others carry [[handgun]]s. [[Submachine gun]]s and even [[assault rifle]]s maybe equipped by those officers in some countries. These guards are required to have firearms training before they can carry them.
Six member states of the European Union prohibit weapons during cash-in-transit (CIT) operations.<ref name="coess">[http://www.coess.org/pdf/CIT_legislations.pdf ''A comparative overview of the legislations governing the Cash in Transit private industry in the 15 EU members''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105230144/http://www.coess.org/pdf/CIT_legislations.pdf |date=2009-01-05 }} (PDF). CoESS / UNI-Europa joint Report. October 2004, p. 14.</ref>
They are also required to wear [[bullet-proof vest]]s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pssg.gov.bc.ca/securityindustry/worker/docs/armoured-car-guard.pdf|title=Specific Requirements and Training for a ARMOURED CAR GUARD|publisher= BC Ministry of Justice|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806074220/http://www.pssg.gov.bc.ca/securityindustry/worker/docs/armoured-car-guard.pdf|archivedate= August 6, 2009|date=June 2009 }}</ref> and/or ballistic helmets.
==See also== * [[Great Train Robbery (1963)]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cash-In-Transit}} [[Category:Logistics]] [[Category:Security]] [[Category:Cash]]

revision.comment: /* Types of forms */ Fixed grammar
revision.text:
A '''Customs declaration''' is a [[Form (document)|form]] that lists the details of goods that are being imported or exported when a citizen or visitor enters a [[customs territory]] (country's borders).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/business/customs-procedures/general-overview/customs-declaration_en|title=Customs declaration|website=European Commission}}</ref> Most countries require travellers to complete a customs declaration form when bringing notified goods ([[alcoholic drink]]s, [[tobacco products]], animals, fresh food, plant material, seeds, [[soil]]s, meats, and [[animal product]]s) across international borders. Posting items via international mail also requires the sending party to complete a customs declaration form.
The declaration form helps the customs to control the goods that entered the country, which can affect the country's economy, security or environment. A levy [[Tariff#Customs duty|duty]] may be applied.
Travellers have to declare everything they acquired abroad and possibly pay [[customs]] duty tax on goods. Some countries offer a duty-free allowance of certain products which may not need to be declared explicitly.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/duty-free-goods|title=Bringing goods into the UK|website=GOV.UK}}</ref>
==Types of forms== * When an individual is transporting the goods, the form is called a customs arrival card, or a landing card, or an entry voucher. The traveller is required to fill out the form, sign and submit to the customs or border protection officer before entering the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atacarnet.com/carnet-countries |title=Carnet Countries|website=atacsrnet.com - Corporation for International Business}}</ref> *When an individual or an organization ships goods across the borders, one must use other customs declaration forms, such as a [[commercial invoice]], or a [[Pro forma#Invoices|proforma invoice]], an import declaration form, an [[ATA Carnet]], or a re-[[export]] declaration. [[Incoterms]] on these forms define the shipment and customs declaration. An [[Harmonized System|Harmonized System Code]] (Hs code or harmonized code) might be required to define the type of goods and their associated tax rate. The importer is usually required to provide information about the goods' country of origin and the [[certificate of origin]]. Errors on the forms can cause delays or confiscation of the goods. For that reason, importers often use a [[customs brokerage]] to clear goods through customs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://help.cbp.gov/app/answers/detail/a_id/418/~/importers---who-needs-a-customs-broker-to-help-clear-goods-through-cbp|website= US Customs and Border Patrol|title=Importers - Who needs a Customs Broker to Help Clear Goods Through CBP?}}</ref>
Some nations require a customs declaration form from each person crossing the border, while other nations require one form per family traveling together. A family is usually defined as family members residing in the same household, who are related by marriage, adoption, blood, or domestic relationship.<ref name="cbp.gov">{{cite web|url=https://www.cbp.gov/travel/CBP-declaration-form-6059B |website=U.S. Customs and Border Protection |title=Declaration Form 6059B, CBP Issues New Customs Declarations Form, Features Expanded Definition of Family Members}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.stats.govt.nz/domino/external/quest/sddquest.nsf/12df43879eb9b25e4c256809001ee0fe/9226dae2ca1cf9564c2569650002caeb?OpenDocument|title=NZIS431 - New Zealand Passenger Departure Card|website=Statistics New Zealand|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015173611/http://www2.stats.govt.nz/domino/external/quest/sddquest.nsf/12df43879eb9b25e4c256809001ee0fe/9226dae2ca1cf9564c2569650002caeb?OpenDocument|archivedate=2008-10-15|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.immi.gov.au/managing-australias-borders/border-security/travel/passenger-cards/index.htm |title=Passenger Cards|author=Department of Immigration and Citizenship|website= Australian Government}}</ref>
[[File:US CBP Form 6059B.png|thumb|right|U.S. Customs and Border Protection Form 6059B (arrival card)]]
==Selected jurisdictions== ===Kuwait=== The [[Kuwait]] Customs *Alcohol of all kinds is forbidden to enter. *Materials containing packaging. In quantities. Will be considered commercial and require a temporary import license *Fees for commercial materials 5% *Customs Broker www.eacct.net/customs/
===Australia=== The [[Australian Customs Service]] handles the customs imports and exports of [[Australia]].<ref>[http://www.australia.gov.au/information-and-services/passports-and-travel/customs-and-quarantine Australian Customs Service]</ref>
===Canada=== Customs declaration managed by the [[Canada Border Services Agency]]: * Each Canadian resident returning to Canada can have a personal exception on goods and gifts purchased or received in another country. Personal exceptions are based on the length of the absence from the country. 24 hours, 48 hours, or 7 days. *Alcohol limitations: 1.5 L of wine or 1.14 L of liquor or 24 x 355 ml cans or bottles (8.5 L) of beer or ale. (Must be of legal age in the province of importation.) Tobacco limitations, 200 cigarettes, 200 tobacco sticks, 50 cigars or cigarillos and 200 grams of manufactured tobacco (Special Duty may apply). *Each individual must declare travelling with $10,000 or more in cash.<ref>[http://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca/publications/forms-formulaires/e311-eng.pdf Canada Customs declaration]</ref><ref>[http://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca/travel-voyage/ivc-rnc-eng.html Canada Customs, Travelers, Visitors to Canada]</ref>
===China=== {{main|Customs clearance in China}} [[General Administration of Customs]] handles the customs imports and exports for the [[Government of China]].<ref>[http://english.customs.gov.cn/ China, General Administration of Customs]</ref><ref>[http://english.customs.gov.cn/Statics/7d65e215-13ed-4a3e-baa1-797f01e5e902.html People's Republic of China, Standards on Completion of Customs Declaration Forms for Import/Export Goods, 08/26/2005]</ref>
===European Union=== The [[European Union]] has a [[European Commission]] for Taxation and Customs Union. The [[European Union Customs Union]] sets trade in the EU. The [[European Customs Information Portal]] is an importing and exporting service provided by the EU.<ref>[https://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/index_en European Commission for Taxation and Customs Union]</ref><ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/common/faq/customs/faq_1178_en.htm FAQ: Customs, Taxation and Customs Union], European Commission, Retrieved 20 August 2016.</ref> Some territories within the EU do not participate in the customs union, usually as a result of their geographic circumstances. Through agreements, the EU has customs unions with [[Andorra]], [[San Marino]], and [[Turkey]] respectively, with the exceptions of certain goods.<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/customs/customs_duties/rules_origin/customs_unions/index_en.htm EU Customs unions, Taxation and Customs Union], European Commission. Retrieved 20 August 2016.</ref><ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/business/customs-procedures/general-overview/customs-declaration_en EU, Customs declaration]</ref>
===Hong Kong=== The [[Customs and Excise Department (Hong Kong)|Customs and Excise Department]] handles the customs imports and exports for [[Hong Kong]].<ref>[http://www.customs.gov.hk Hong Kong Customs and Excise (official website)] {{en icon}} {{zh icon}}</ref> <ref>[http://www.customs.gov.hk/en/cargo_clearance/declaration/lodgement/types/ Hong Kong, Types of Declaration Forms]</ref>
===India=== The [[Central Board of Excise and Customs]] handles the customs imports and exports of [[India]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/gfaXskjgXYGaCTqUchfNvO/Arriving-at-a-consensus-with-states-critical-for-GST-impleme.html |title=India, Arriving at consensus with states critical to implement GST: Hasmukh Adhia |work=[[Live Mint]] |date=6 August 2016 }}</ref>
===Indonesia=== The [[Directorate General of Customs and Excise (Indonesia)|Directorate General of Customs and Excise]] handles the customs imports and exports of [[Indonesia]].<ref>[http://www.beacukai.go.id/faq/ketentuan-barang-bawaan-penumpang.html Indonesia Customs and Excise (official website)] {{en icon}} {{id icon}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== The [[New Zealand Customs Service]] handles the customs imports and exports of [[New Zealand]].<ref>[http://www.customs.govt.nz/Pages/default.aspx New Zealand Customs Service]</ref><ref>[http://www.customs.govt.nz/outcommercial/preparetoexport/declarations/Pages/default.aspx New Zealand commercial declaration]</ref>
===Pakistan=== [[Pakistan Customs]] handles the customs imports and exports for [[Pakistan]] and control of the [[list of tariffs in Pakistan]].<ref>[http://www.fbr.gov.pk Pakistan Customs]</ref>
===Philippines=== The [[Bureau of Customs]] handles the customs imports and exports for [[Philippines]].<ref>[http://customs.gov.ph/ Philippines Bureau of Customs]</ref>
===Poland=== The [[Customs Service (Poland)|Customs Service of Poland]] handles the customs imports and exports for [[Poland]]<ref>[http://www.mf.gov.pl/en/customs-service/customs-service/history Customs Service of Poland]</ref>
===Russia=== The [[Federal Customs Service of Russia]] handles the customs imports and exports for the [[Russia]]. [[Russian Customs Tariff]] cover the Federal Customs Service of Russia <ref>[http://www.fms.gov.ru/ Federal Customs Service of Russia]</ref>
===Singapore=== [[Singapore Customs]] handles the customs imports and exports for [[Singapore]].<ref>[http://www.customs.gov.sg, Singapore Customs]</ref>
===South Korea=== [[Korea Customs Service]] handles the customs imports and exports for [[South Korea]].<ref>[http://www.customs.go.kr/ Korea Customs Service, Official website] {{ko icon}}</ref>
===Sri Lanka=== [[Sri Lanka Customs]] handles the customs imports and exports for [[Sri Lanka]]<ref>[http://www.customs.gov.lk/ Sri Lanka Customs at] www.customs.gov.lk</ref>
===Sweden=== The [[Swedish Customs Service]] handles the customs imports and exports for [[Sweden]].<ref>[http://www.tullverket.se/en/startpage.4.4ab1598c11632f3ba9280002814.html Swedish Customs Service]</ref>
===United Kingdom=== The [[UK Border Agency]] handles customs in the [[United Kingdom]]. The UK Border Agency works with [[HM Revenue and Customs]].<ref>"[http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/border_review.aspx Security in a global hub – Establishing the UK’s new border arrangements] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906193105/http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/border_review.aspx |date=2008-09-06 }}". Cabinet Office. Last updated 16 June 2009.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/uk-border-agency |title=UK Border Agency |year=2013 |publisher=GOV.UK |accessdate=27 March 2013}}</ref> [[File:UKBA and Police.jpg|thumb|right|The UKBA often cooperated with the Police, such as at this customs raid. The officer on the left is a [[Police Community Support Officer]] (PCSO)]]
===United States=== {{main|Customs duties in the United States}} [[Image:Global Entry Kiosk.jpg|thumb|U.S. [[Global Entry]] Kiosks, that can make a Customs declaration for the traveller.]] * [[U.S. Customs]] asks the Head of a household to complete the form (CBP Form 6059B {{as of|2016|July|lc=y}}). Family members residing in the same household, who are related by marriage, adoption, blood, or domestic relationship, can use one form. *For returning U.S. residents: The personal duty exemption for each family member is $800.00. For example, a family of five members returning is allowed a combined personal duty exemption of $4,000 (calculated as $800 for each family member multiplied by 5).<ref name="cbp.gov" /><ref>[https://www.cbp.gov/travel/us-citizens cbp.gov, US Customs, US Citizens travelling]</ref> * For international visitors: US laws allow visitors some exemptions, like tobacco, gifts, personal effects, etc. The head of a household can complete a form for a family. It is good to check the current duties and exemptions to avoid tax or loss of goods. *Anyone travelling with more than $10,000 must declare it.<ref name="cbp.gov" /><ref>[https://www.cbp.gov/travel/international-visitors cbp.gov, US Customs, US international visitors]</ref><ref>[https://www.cbp.gov/travel/canadian-and-mexican-citizens# cbp.gov, US Customs, For Canadian and Mexican Citizens]</ref>
[[File:shannon2.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Shannon Airport]] preclearance]]
* At some [[international airport]]s, the US operates [[United States border preclearance]] stations, where [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] is done before boarding the international flight.<ref>Batrawy, Aya. (January 26, 2014.) "[https://web.archive.org/web/20140126203639/http://www.seattlepi.com/news/world/article/US-Customs-passenger-facility-opens-in-UAE-5176441.php US Customs passenger facility opens in UAE]". ''Associated Press''. Seattle Post Intelligencer. Archived from [http://www.seattlepi.com/news/world/article/US-Customs-passenger-facility-opens-in-UAE-5176441.php the original] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140126203639/http://www.seattlepi.com/news/world/article/US-Customs-passenger-facility-opens-in-UAE-5176441.php |date=January 26, 2014 }} on January 26, 2014.</ref> * If exporting goods that are valued more than $2,500, an extra form is required: the Electronic Export Information (EEI) form. The [[Automated Export System]] (AES) is the system used by [[United States|U.S.]] exporters to electronically declare their international exports. This information is used by the [[United States Census Bureau|Census Bureau]] to help compile U.S. export and trade statistics.<ref>[https://help.cbp.gov/app/answers/detail/a_id/292/~/when-to-apply-for-an-electronic-export-information-(eei) cbp.gov, US Customs, When to apply for an Electronic Export Information (EEI)]</ref>

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5.1)
revision.text:
'''Deinking''' is the [[industrial process]] of removing [[printing ink]] from [[Fiber crop|paperfibers]] of [[recycled paper]] to make [[deinked pulp]].
The key in the deinking process is the ability to detach ink from the fibers. This is achieved by a combination of mechanical action and chemical means. In Europe the most common process is [[froth flotation]] deinking.
Paper is one of the main targets for [[Paper recycling|recycling]]. A concern about recycling [[wood pulp]] paper is that the fibers are degraded with each cycle and after being recycled 4–6 times the fibers become too short and weak to be useful in making paper.<ref name="paperinfosheet">{{cite web |title=Paper Recycling Information Sheet|url=http://www.wasteonline.org.uk/resources/InformationSheets/paper.htm |publisher=Waste Online |accessdate= October 20, 2007 }}</ref>
==History== {{see also|history of paper}} Before the invention of the [[paper machine]] in 1799 the most common fibre source was recycled fibres from used textiles, hence the name [[rag paper]]. The rags were from [[hemp]], [[linen]] and [[cotton]]. It was not until the introduction of [[wood pulp]] in 1843 that paper production was independent of recycled materials.<ref name=PST1>{{cite book |last1=Göttsching|first1=Lothar|authorlink1= |last2=Pakarinen |first2=Heikki |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=Recycled Fiber and Deinking|url= |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= Papermaking Science and Technology |volume= 7 |year= 2000|origyear= |publisher= Fapet Oy|location= Finland|isbn= 952-5216-07-1 |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= 12–14 |chapter= 1|chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref>
[[Paper recycling|Recycling of used paper]] before the [[industrialisation]] of paper production, rag paper was recycled to make low-grade [[Paperboard|board]]. A process for removing printing inks from recycled paper was invented by [[German people|German]] jurist [[Justus Claproth]] in 1774.<ref name=PST1 /> He practiced together with German paper producer [[Johann Engelhard Schmid]]. Today this method is called deinking.
First in the 1950s and 1960s the use of recycled fibres from paper made of wood pulp begun to increase, and was mainly used in packaging paper and paperboard. In the 1950s the [[froth flotation]] technique was adapted for deinking [[recycled paper]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Handbook of Pulp |editor1-last=Sixta |editor1-first=Herbert |authorlink= |year=2006 |publisher=Wiley-VCH |location=Germany |isbn=3-527-30999-3 |volume=2 |page=1174 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> Use of recovered paper increased in the 1970s mainly in graphic and hygienic papers, and accelerated in the 1980s. The annual growth in use of recovered paper increased by 6% between 1980 and 1996. The use of virgin fibres only increased 2% in the same period. In 1997 recovered paper production was 42% of the total paper production.<ref name=PST1 />
==Deinking process== [[File:Deinking (schematic layout).svg|thumb|right|350px|Schematic layout of a deinking plant.]]
===Sorting=== Waste paper may contain a mixture of different [[Paper#Applications|paper types]] made of mixtures of different paperfibers. These must be sorted before processed. Broke (paper waste from paper production) is normally used directly in the [[papermachine]]. * Office waste (OW) * Old [[magazine paper]]s (OMP) * Old [[newspaper|newsprint]] (ONP) * [[Paperboard]] * [[Corrugated fiberboard]] Recycled paper can be used to make paper of the same or lower quality than it was originally. The sorted paper is baled and shipped to a [[papermill]]. The pulpmill uses waste paper grade according to the paper quality they want to make.
===Debaling=== The bales are opened and large foreign objects are sorted out on the [[conveyor belt]] to the [[pulper]]. Many extraneous materials are readily removed. Twine, strapping, etc. are removed from the hydropulper by a "ragger". Metal straps and staples can be screened out or removed by a magnet. Film-backed pressure-sensitive tape stays intact: the PSA adhesive and the backing are both removed together.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pstc.org/technical_notes/to_recycle.php?subject=packaging |title=Packaging Tapes: To Recycle of Not |accessdate=2007-11-06 |last=Jensen |first=Timothy |date=April 1999 |publisher=Adhesives and Sealants Council |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109204909/http://www.pstc.org/technical_notes/to_recycle.php?subject=packaging |archivedate=2007-11-09 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Pulping=== Pulpers are either batch, which uses a tub with a high shear rotor, or continuous, using a long, perforated drum. Drum pulpers are very expensive but have the advantage of not breaking up contaminants, thus giving cleaner end product.
The pulper chops the paper to smaller pieces; water and chemicals are added. Normally the [[pH]] is adjusted to 8.5 - 10.0. Normal deinking chemicals are: * pH control: [[sodium silicate]] or [[sodium hydroxide]] * Bleaching: [[hydrogen peroxide]] * [[Calcium]] [[ion]] source: [[hard water]], [[lime (material)|lime]] or [[calcium chloride]] * Collector: [[fatty acid]], fatty acid [[emulsion]], fatty acid [[soap]] or organo-modified [[siloxane]]<ref>{{Cite patent | inventor-last = Nellesen | inventor-first = Bernhard | inventorlink = | inventor2-last = Northfleet | inventor2-first = Christina | inventorlink2 = | publication-date = 05.02.2004 | issue-date = 2004 | title = METHOD OF DEINKING | country-code = WO | postscript = <!--None--> | description = | patent-number = 011717 }} </ref> After pulping, the mixture is a [[slurry]]. The slurry goes to [[Kraft process#Screening|screening]].
===Cleaning and screening=== [[Centrifugal cleaning]] is spinning the pulp slurry in a cleaner, causing materials that are denser than pulp fibers to move outward and be rejected. [[Sieve|Screens]], with either slots or holes, are used to remove contaminants that are larger than pulp fibers.
Materials which are more difficult to remove include wax coatings on corrugated cartons and '''[[stickies (papermaking)|stickies]]''', soft rubbery particles which can make deposits and contaminate the recycled paper. Stickies can originate from [[book binding]]s, [[hot melt adhesive]]s, PSA [[adhesive]]s from paper labels, [[laminating]] adhesives of reinforced gummed [[Adhesive tape|tapes]], etc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tlmi.com/recycling-standards.php |title=Recycling Compatible Adhesives Standards |accessdate=2007-11-06 |year=2007 |publisher=Tag and Label Manufacturers Institute |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109230413/http://www.tlmi.com/recycling-standards.php |archivedate=2007-11-09 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corrugated.org/Upload/Files/WaxAlternativesStandard.pdf |title=Voluntary Standard for Repulping and Recycling Corugated Fiberboard |accessdate=2007-11-06 |year=2005 |publisher=Corrugated Packaging Alliance |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071203163418/http://www.corrugated.org/Upload/Files/WaxAlternativesStandard.pdf |archivedate=2007-12-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fpl.fs.fed.us/documnts/pdf1998/seite98a.pdf |title=Environmentally benign USPS stamps | accessdate = 2007-11-08 |last=Seiter, Pikulin, |first= |date=October 1998 |publisher=TAPPI Pulping Conference|format=PDF}}</ref>
===Deinking stage=== In the deinking stage the goal is to release and remove the [[hydrophobic]] contaminants from the recycled paper. The contaminants are mostly [[printing ink]] and [[stickies (papermaking)|stickies]]. Several processes are used, most commonly flotation or washing.
====Flotation deinking==== [[Image:FlCell.PNG|thumb|240px|right|Diagram of a [[froth flotation]] cell.]] [[Froth flotation]] was adapted from the flotation process used in the [[mining industry]] in the 1960s. It is the most common deinking process in [[Europe]] used to recover [[recycled paper]]. Often most of the collector is added to the inlet of the flotation. The process temperatures are normally in the range 45 - 55 °C. [[Air]] is blown into the pulp [[Suspension (chemistry)|suspension]]. The collector has [[Chemical affinity|affinity]] both to the ink particles and air bubbles, causing them to attach. The air bubbles lift the ink to the surface and form a thick [[froth]] that can be removed. Normally the setup is a two stage system with 3, 4 or 5 flotation cells in series.<ref>Voith EcoCell flotation plant {{cite web |url=http://www.voithpaper.com/applications/productsearch/files/594_VPR-PB-07-0001-GB-07.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090824075218/http://www.voithpaper.com/applications/productsearch/files/594_VPR-PB-07-0001-GB-07.pdf |archivedate=2009-08-24 |df= }}</ref> Flotation deinking is very effective in removing ink particles larger than about 10 µm.
====Wash deinking==== Wash deinking consists of a washing stage where [[dispersant]]s are added to wash out the [[printing ink]]s. When the pulp slurry is [[dewatering|dewatered]] (thickened), the medium to fine particles are [[Washing|washed]] out. This process is most useful for removing particles smaller than about 30 µm, like water-based inks, fillers, coating particles, fines and [[stickies (papermaking)|micro stickies]]. This process is more common when making [[deinked pulp]] for [[Facial tissue|tissue]]. The processing equipment are [[belt filter]]s, pressure belt filters, [[disk filter]]s and static [[Water filter|filters]]. This stage is much more efficient than normal washing / dewatering stages.
====Combined washing and flotation==== High quality deinking of office wastes and other printing papers often commonly uses a combination of washing and flotation.
====Enzymatic deinking==== This method of deinking uses industrial or food grade enzymes in conjunction with flotation deinking to aid in the removal of inks in recycling mills. More efficient removal of ink increases fiber yield, decreases dirt count, and increases paper brightness. Often the use of enzymatic deinking helps mills reduce their bleach usage or use cheaper furnish.
====Other deinking processes==== [[Dissolved air flotation]] (DAF) is used by some mills in the deinking stage and will remove some ink and filler (ash); however, it is mainly used to clarify the process water.
===Washing / dewatering=== Washing / dewatering (thickening) is a filtration process. Small particles (< 5 µm) are removed by passing water through the pulp.
===Bleaching=== {{Main|Bleaching of wood pulp}}
If white paper is desired, [[bleaching of wood pulp|bleaching]] uses [[peroxide]]s or [[sodium dithionite|hydrosulfites]] to increase the [[brightness]] of the pulp. The bleaching methods are similar for mechanical pulp, but the goal is to make the fiber brighter.
===Papermaking=== The deinked fiber is made into a new paper product in the same way that virgin [[wood fiber]], see [[papermaking]].
===Byproducts=== The unusable material left over, mainly ink, plastics, filler and short fibers, is called '''sludge'''. The sludge is buried in a landfill, burned to create energy at the paper mill or used as a fertilizer by local farmers.
===Problems=== Water based [[flexo]]graphic printing inks with [[particle size]]s below 5 µm and poor solubility in [[alkaline]] conditions may cause problems in deinking, especially in the flotation stage. The solution is to use an extra [[acidic]] washing stage.
Temperature control is important as this affects the stickiness of [[stickies (papermaking)|stickies]].
Additional issues arise when taking into account the number of chemicals potentially present in paper for recycling. Studies have indicated that paper might contain as many as 10,000 different chemicals,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Waste paper for recycling: Overview and identification of potentially critical substances|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0956053X15001312|journal = Waste Management|doi = 10.1016/j.wasman.2015.02.028|first = Kostyantyn|last = Pivnenko|first2 = Eva|last2 = Eriksson|first3 = Thomas F.|last3 = Astrup}}</ref> fate of which in the deinking process still remains unknown.
==See also== * [[Dissolved air flotation]] * [[Environmental issues with paper]] * [[Froth flotation]] * [[German inventors and discoverers]] * [[Paper recycling]] * [[Pulp & Paper chemicals]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book | last = Göttsching| first = Lothar| authorlink = |author2=Pakarinen, Heikki | title = Papermaking Science and Technology: 7. Recycled Fiber and Deinking | publisher = | year = 2000 | location = Finland | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 952-5216-07-1}}
{{Paper}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Dick Enthoven |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Richard Enthoven |birth_date = |birth_place = South Africa |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |nationality = South African |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = owner of [[Nando's]], [[Hollard Group]] and [[Spier Wine Farm]] |education = |alma_mater = [[University of Southern California]]
[[London School of Economics]] |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = US$1.1 [[billion]] (October 2015) |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |boards = |religion = |partner = |children = 3, including [[Robby Enthoven|Robby]] |parents = [[Patrick Enthoven]] |relations = |website = }} '''Richard "Dick" Enthoven''' is a South African [[billionaire]] businessman, the owner of the casual dining chain [[Nando's]], the [[Hollard Group]] of insurance companies, and Spier Wine Farm. ==Early life== Richard Enthoven is the son of [[Patrick Enthoven]],{{cite news|title=Our clients benefit by us backing winners like Hollard|url=http://www.bib.co.za/news/entry/our-clients-benefit-by-us-backing-winners-like-hollard/|accessdate=29 October 2015|work=Barker Insurance Brokers|date=25 January 2011}} and the grandson of Robert Enthoven, a Dutch entrepreneur who "amassed an insurance fortune", with his company Robert Enthoven Insurance Brokers. He has a BA degree from the [[University of Southern California]], and an MSc degree from the [[London School of Economics]].{{cite web|title=Executive Profile Richard Enthoven|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=111651810&privcapId=47063896|website=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=29 October 2015}} ==Career== Enthoven started his career working for [[American International Group]] as regional underwriting assistant for South America. From 1996 to 1998, he worked as project manager for [[Progressive Corporation|United Financial Casualty Company]] and then for IVM Holdings, Inc. In 1999, he moved to Sydney and established [[Hollard Group|Hollard Insurance]] in Australia. Enthoven owns [[Nando's]] casual dining chain, [[Spier Wine Farm]] and the [[Hollard Group]] of insurance companies.{{cite news|last1=Pietzsch|first1=Mareike|title=Meet the reclusive South African billionaire investor behind Nando’s|url=http://www.thesouthafrican.com/meet-the-reclusive-sa-tycoon-behind-nandos/|accessdate=29 October 2015|work=thesouthafrican|date=23 April 2015}} As of March 2015, ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' estimated his net worth at US$1.1 billion.{{cite news|last1=Pendleton|first1=Devon|title=Spicy Chicken Billionaire Springs From South Africa With Nando’s|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-19/spicy-chicken-billionaire-springs-from-south-africa-with-nando-s|accessdate=29 October 2015|work=Bloomberg L.P.|date=19 March 2015}} ==Personal life== He has three children, Robby, Adrian, and Mariota. [[Robby Enthoven]] heads the UK operation of Nando’s. Adrian Enthoven was educated at Oxford University and is now chairman of Hollard Group. Mariota Enthoven is married to Angus McIntosh and they run the Spier Biodynamic Farm. He has a collection of 5,000 South African artworks, which are displayed in Nando's branches. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Enthoven, Dick}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Southern California alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of the London School of Economics]] [[Category:South African businesspeople]] [[Category:South African billionaires]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=September 2013}} '''Economic consulting''' is the practice of providing organizations in the public and private sector with information to improve their performance and policies, primarily through the use of [[Applied Economics|applied economics]], [[mathematical economics]], [[economic impact analysis]], and forecasting across a broad spectrum of issues. Economic consulting may be applied throughout society, as in [[business]], [[finance]], [[health care]], and [[government]], but also to such diverse subjects as [[crime]], [[education]], the [[family]], [[law]], [[politics]], [[religion]], [[social institutions]], [[war]], and [[science]].
==Related== *[[Applied Economics|Applied economics]] *[[Mathematical economics]]
[[Category:Consultants|*]] [[Category:Consulting occupations|*]] [[Category:Business occupations]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Elkhan Mammadov | image =Elkhan_Mammadov_during_FIFA_U-17_Women%27s_World_Cup.jpg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|6|18|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijani SSR]], [[USSR]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | occupation = General Secretary of [[Association of Football Federations of Azerbaijan]] | salary = | title = | term = | predecessor = Fuad Asadov | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = | children = 3 | website = | footnotes = | religion = | known = | relations = }}
'''Elkhan Mammadov''' is a General Secretary of [[Association of Football Federations of Azerbaijan]] (AFFA), Project Leader for [[UEFA Euro 2020|UEFA EURO 2020]] Baku Bid, Vice-President of UEFA Fair Play and Social Responsibility Committee, FIFA Fair Play and Social Responsibility Committee Member.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thebusinessyear.com/azerbaijan-2015/back-of-the-net/interview|title=Back of The Net|website=The Business Year|access-date=2016-11-09}}</ref>
==Biography== Elkhan Mammadov was born in 1979 in [[Baku|Baku, Azerbaijan.]]
=== Education === Mammadov received his bachelor's degree in Business Administration and Corporate Management from American InterContinental University ([[London|London, UK]]) in 1999.
In 2011 Elkhan Mammadov participated in Football Clubs and Association’s Management Executive Training conducted by [[University of Liverpool]]. He also completed his postgraduate studies in Planning Management at [[University of Salford]] ([[Manchester|Manchester, UK]]) in 2012.<ref name=":0"/>
In 2016 Elkhan Mammadov graduated from The Executive Master in European Sport Governance (MESGO) programme, organized in cooperation with Sciences Po institute in [[Paris]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mesgo.org/2016/04/19/graduation-ceremony-mesgo-iii/|title=Successful MESGO III participants graduated at UEFA headquarters|last=team|first=MESGO|date=2016-04-19|website=MESGO|access-date=2016-11-09}}</ref>
===Career=== Worked as logistical operations controller’s assistant in Baku Investment Ltd in 1996-1997. Upon graduation from American InterContinental University, worked as Deputy Director at Natavan Business Centre and then, Managing Director at Natavan Company and Baku Investment Ltd. In 2000-2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thebusinessyear.com/azerbaijan-2013/field-of-play/interview|title=Field of Play|website=The Business Year|access-date=2016-11-11}}</ref>
==== AFFA ==== Elkhan Mammadov became General Secretary of AFFA in July 2007. Currently, Mammadov also holds the title of Vice-President at UEFA Fair Play and Social Responsibility Committee (since 2008) and is a member of [[FIFA]] Fair Play and Social Responsibility Committee. He performed as UEFA Delegate during 2009-2012.
Mammadov was a member and a chairman of various bidding committees for Azerbaijan to host international sporting events. This includes, bidding for [http://www.baku2015.com/ 2015 European Games], Baku 2020 Olympics and various large-scale football events. Under his chairmanship, Azerbaijan received the right to host [https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u17womensworldcup/azerbaijan2012/ 2012 FIFA Under-17 Women’s World Cup], 2016 [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship|UEFA Under-17 European Championship]] and most lately, three group stage and one quarter-final matches of EURO 2020, that was announced by UEFA in September 2014.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro-2020/news/newsid=2389885.html|title=Everything you need to know about UEFA EURO 2020 - UEFA EURO 2020 - News - UEFA.com|last=UEFA.com|website=UEFA.com|access-date=2016-11-11}}</ref>
Upon taking office as AFFA General Secretary, Mammadov initiated reformation of Association structure – which resulted in such new departments as Registration and Statistics, Women’s Leagues, Information Technologies, and others – and facilitated adoption of AFFA strategy with three defined priorities: Education, Infrastructure and Grassroots.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://leadersinsport.com/people/elkhan-mammadov/|title=Elkhan Mammadov - Leaders|newspaper=Leaders|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-11}}</ref>
In 2013 AFFA received Women and Sport Achievement Diploma from [[International Olympic Committee]] for its contribution to the development and popularization of women's and girls' football.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.uefa.org/football-development/womens-football/programme/news/newsid=2039306.html|title=Development - News - Football development – UEFA.org|last=uefa.com|date=2013-12-18|newspaper=UEFA.com|access-date=2016-11-11}}</ref>
In 2014 AFFA together with its partner, Bakcell, started cooperation with Manchester United Football Club: young football players receive a chance to train with coaches of one of the leading football clubs in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bakcell.com/en/06/2013/bakcell-brings-manchester-united-soccer-school-to-azerbaijan|title=Bakcell brings "Manchester United" Soccer School to Azerbaijan! - Bakcell|website=www.bakcell.com|access-date=2016-11-11}}</ref>
Mammadov was appointed for the third consecutive term as General Secretary by President Rovnag Abdullayev and Executive Committee at AFFA Congress in Spring 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.affa.az/index.php/news/meeting-of-the-executive-committee/57327|title=Meeting of the Executive Committee|website=www.affa.az|access-date=2016-11-11}}</ref>
In September 2016, AFFA adopted new development strategy “GROW 2020”, which highlights Association’s priorities until 2020/21 football season.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.affa.az/index.php/news/proqram-layihsi-mzakir-olunub-fotolar/58700|title=Proqram layihəsi müzakirə olunub (fotolar)|website=www.affa.az|access-date=2016-11-11}}</ref>
On October 4, 2016 Elkhan Mammadov received a Leadership Award at “Leaders Under 40 Awards” event in London.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://leadersinsport.com/news/meet-leadership-category/|title=Meet the Leadership Category - Leaders|newspaper=Leaders|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-11}}</ref>
On February 9, 2017 Elkhan Mammadov was announced as one of 13 candidates from UEFA member associations standing for the eight vacant positions on the UEFA Executive Committee for the elections at 41st Ordinary UEFA Congress in early April,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uefa.org/mediaservices/newsid=2440149.html|title=Candidates for election at 41st Ordinary UEFA Congress - UEFA.org|last=UEFA.org|website=UEFA.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-17}}</ref> [http://www.affa.az/files/17573/878/43/2/7_0/Elkhan+Mammadov-2.pdf for which he presented the candidate brochure.]
On December 18, 2017 President of Azerbaijan Republic Ilham Aliyev presented Elkhan Mammadov with the Azerbaijani President`s honorary diploma.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.president.az/articles/26408|title=Ilham Aliyev attended ceremony dedicated to sport results of 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=en.president.az|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-04}}</ref>
Besides his native Azerbaijani, he is fluent in English, Russian and Turkish.
Married with three children.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * http://www.baku2015.com/

{{Like resume|date=November 2010}} {{Infobox person |name = Euh Yoon-Dae
[[Hangul]]: 어윤대
[[Hanja]]: 魚允大 |image = |imagesize = 200px |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1945|05|22}} |birth_place = Jinhae city, [[Gyeongsangnam-do]], [[Korea under Japanese rule|Korea]] |nationality = South Korean |occupation = Professor emeritus, Korea University | alma_mater = [[Korea University]]
[[University of Michigan]] }} {{Infobox Korean name |title = [[Korean name]] |hangul= 어윤대 |hanja={{linktext|魚|允|大}} |rr=Eo Yundae |mr=Ŏ Yundae }} '''Euh Yoon-Dae''' (born 1945) is a [[South Korea]]n [[professor]], [[financier]], and advisor for the [[South Korean government]]. He served as [[Chairman]] of [[KB Kookmin Bank|KB Financial Group]] and of the [[Presidential Council on Nation Branding, Korea]]. ==Childhood and Education== Euh was born in Jinhae city (now [[Changwon]]), [[Gyeongsangnam-do]], [[Korea]] on 22 May 1945. He earned his [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] and [[Master of Business Administration|M.B.A.]] at [[Korea University]], an M.B.A. at the [[Asian Institute of Management]], and a [[Ph.D]]. in [[business administration]] at the [[University of Michigan]]. He has received honorary doctorate degrees at [[Yonsei University]], [[Waseda University]], [[Griffith University]] and [[Renmin University]].{{cite web |url=http://www.korea.edu/board/view.php?code=notice&no=1704 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725175806/http://www.korea.edu/board/view.php?code=notice&no=1704 |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} ==Career== Recently, Euh Yoon-Dae served as Chairman of [[KB Kookmin Bank|KB Financial Group]], Korea's second largest banking group. He was also the first Chairman of the [[Presidential Council on Nation Branding, Korea]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.koreabrand.net/kr/pcnb/pcnb_index.do|title=koreabrand.net|website=www.koreabrand.net|access-date=2018-04-09}} from its establishment in January 2009 to 2010. A former President of [[Korea University]] (2003~2006),{{cite web |url=http://www.korea.edu/board/view.php?code=notice&no=1704 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725175806/http://www.korea.edu/board/view.php?code=notice&no=1704 |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} Euh also served in various advisory roles for the South Korean government. He was also former Vice-Chair of the National Economic Advisory Council, Chairman of Advisory Board of the Ministry of Education and Human Resources, and sat on the Public Fund Oversight Commission. He served as a Monetary Board Member of the [[Bank of Korea]] as well as a Board Member of the [[Korea Development Bank]]. From 1993 to 2004, he served as Policy Advisor for the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade (South Korea)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade]]. He was also Chairman of the Steering Committee of [[Korea Investment Corporation]] (KIC), responsible for setting policies and reviewing management performance.{{cite web |url=http://www.korea.edu/board/view.php?code=notice&no=1704 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725175806/http://www.korea.edu/board/view.php?code=notice&no=1704 |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} Euh was founding President of the Korea Center for International Finance, established in 1999. He previously headed the Korean Academic Society of Business Administration and Korea Monetary and Finance Association. ===KB Financial Group (Chairman): 2010 ~ 2013=== Euh Yoon-Dae was inaugurated as Chairman of [[KB Kookmin Bank|KB Financial Group]][http://www.kbfng.com/Eng/index.jsp KB Financial Group] on July 13, 2010. In his inaugural speech, Euh said the Group needed to slim down and cut costs to achieve its vision of becoming a global bank,{{Cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2923169|title=Euh vows to slim down an ‘obese’ KB|last=|first=|date=|website=koreajoongangdaily|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-09}} and he has launched reforms since then.[http://www.koreaherald.com/business/Detail.jsp?newsMLId=20100728000771 KoreaHerald] retrieved 29th July 2010{{Cite news|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/biz/2010/07/124_70276.html|title=Euh Yoon-dae, second from left, chairman of KB Financial ...|date=2010-07-27|work=koreatimes|access-date=2018-04-09|language=en}} ===Presidential Council on Nation Branding (Chairman): 2009 ~ 2010=== Euh Yoon-Dae was chairman of the [[Presidential Council on Nation Branding, Korea|Presidential Council on Nation Branding]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.koreabrand.net|title=koreabrand.net|website=www.koreabrand.net|access-date=2018-04-09}} He was appointed to this position in January 2009. The Council was established on January 22, 2009 by Executive Decree 21283 with the objective to promote South Korea's global image; to right misconceptions about South Korea, its culture, its products, and its people; and to raise respect for South Korea so as to support South Korean businesses and nationals abroad through governmental initiated strategies and policies.{{cite web|url=http://news.inews24.com/php/news_view.php?g_serial=387911&g_menu=020300|title=국가브랜드위원회 출범…위원장에 어윤대 전 고려대 총장|last=|first=|date=2009-01-22|website=아이뉴스|archiveurl=|archivedate=|deadurl=|accessdate=2018-04-09|df=}} ===Korea University (President): 2003~2006=== During his presidency (2003~2006), 12,000 seats were secured within the library (the largest number of library seats amongst Korean universities), one third of classes were conducted in English, the number of foreign exchange students increased sharply, and modern buildings and shopping malls were built.{{Cite web|url=http://www.korea.ac.kr/do/MessageBoard/ArticleRead.do?forum=kunews&id=4b272f|title=고려대학교|website=www.korea.ac.kr|language=ko|access-date=2018-04-09}} Despite much advancement, Euh failed to be reelected as president. His critics argue that Euh led the school of extreme market principles and internationalism. Prior to his presidency, English classes only amounted 4%. This figure changed to 34% of total classes at Korea University within the four years of his presidency. His supporters agree that most international universities value international competitiveness and administer their schools accordingly. Euh has also succeeded in raising 470 billion [[South Korean won|Korean won]] as a University Development Fund. ===Other Experiences=== *2011~current: Board Member, The Institute of International Finance *2010~current: Member, Bretton Woods Committee *2008~2010: Chairman, Steering Committee of [[Korea Investment Corporation]] (KIC) *2007~current: Member, Board of Governors, [[Asian Institute of Management]] *2005~2006: Vice Chair, National Economic Advisory Council *2003~2004: Chair, Advisory Board of the Ministry of Education and Human Resources *2001~2003: Member (Minister), Public Fund Oversight Commission *1999~2003: Board Member, CJ Home Shopping *1999~2000: Founding President, Korea Center for International Finance *1998~2002: Board Member, [[Hyundai Corporation]] *1998~1999: Board Member, [[Korea First Bank]] *1996~1999: Director (Non-Resident), Korea Institute for Public Finance *1996~1997: Board Member, [[Korea Development Bank]] *1992~1995: Monetary Board Member, [[The Bank of Korea]] ==Family== Euh Yoon-Dae is married to Jhong Bok-Joo (62), Professor at [[Ewha Womans University]] College of Music with two sons. ==Honors and awards== *[[Beta Gamma Sigma]], [[University of Michigan]] (Ph.D.) *The Marquis Who’s Who In The World *Asian Institute of Management Triple A Award *Distinguished Alumni of the Year by Kyung-gi High School *A Merit, ''Les Insignes de Chevalier de l’[[Ordre national du Mérite]]'' from French Government *Order of Service Merit (Blue Stripes) *The Most Powerful Business Leaders in Korea Award from Fortune Korea *Dasan Finance Prize from Financial Services Commission and Hankyung Daily (2012) ==Research and Publications== === Books === *Commercial Banks and Creditworthiness of LDCs (UMI Research Press; Ann Arbor, 1979) *The
